headline: Pork Carnitas
description: This Dutch oven carnitas recipe is made with seared, seasoned pork slow-cooked in a Dutch oven until tender before gently shredded apart with forks.

video.description: A very easy and flavorful Mexican-inspired pork dish.
video.name: Pork Carnitas

name: Pork Carnitas
recipeIngredient: 4 pounds pork shoulder, cut into several large pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Heat vegetable oil in a large Dutch oven over high heat. Season pork shoulder pieces with salt, then arrange in the Dutch oven. Cook until browned on all sides, about 10 minutes.
Stir in onion, garlic, lime juice, chili powder, oregano, and cumin. Pour in chicken broth; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until pork is very tender, about 2 1/2 hours.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
Transfer pork shoulder to a large baking sheet; reserve cooking liquid. Drizzle a small amount of cooking liquid over pork pieces and lightly season with salt.
Bake pork in the preheated oven until browned, about 30 minutes. Drizzle more cooking liquid every 10 minutes; use two forks to shred pork as it browns.

review.reviewBody: This is so good. I've made this twice now and every time it gets so many complements!

I've made this recipe alot it is better than any restaurant carnitas I've tried. That being said use your head with the salt 3 Tbsp is wayyyy too much I use 1 Tbsp and also I increase the oven time by approximately 15 minutes . The end product is slightly crispy on the outside and buttery on the inside.....

I halved this; using 2lbs pork shoulder BUT leaving the onions, garlic, cumin and oregano (used Mexican oregano only because I had it) as if I was making the 4lb version. This is AMAZING! And the aromas over the 3 hour cook time were mouthwatering torture! The photo is taken immediately after removed from the oven. Did I say this was amazing??!! It was!! Already pinned to make again for Cinco de Mayo and I also plan to make sure I make the full recipe because right now, I wish we had leftovers! Top notch recipe Nette!!

An absolute hit with everyone I've served this to. I don't change a thing other than tossing in some extra garlic because there's no such thing as too much garlic. Rather than shredding with two forks, I use one of those ground beef masher thingys. It works much faster and you don't wind up with the fork tines stuck between each other. The only other thing I'd say is to give yourself an extra half hour above the total prep/cook time. Unless you're a 3rd-degree blackbelt kitchen ninja, there's no way you're getting all the prep and the meat browned in 30-45 minutes.

I made this as directed with the exception of the pork as I had lefover pork roast that was already shredded for pulled pork. I halved the recipe based upon the amount of port I had available. I did add one can of mild diced green chilis and a couple tablespoons of chopped jalapeno. Since I used pork that was already cooked, I made the sauce and brought it to a boil and tasted to ensure the flavor was there before adding the pork. I simmered on low heat for 45 minutes before transferring to the sheet pan. I finished the recipe as printed. This was very tasty and will be making again.

I have made this recipe a few times with a couple small but tasty tweaks. I substituted Mexican beer for 1/2 of the broth, added about a shot of Tequila and a dash of cayenne pepper to the broth. I also increased the baking time enough to get all the meat a little crispy on the outside.

Loved it! Used 8 cloves garlic smashed per author's updated note. Only used 2 cups broth based on size of roast. Braised in 325 oven for 99 minutes. This was the hit of my Mexican themed dinner party!

Outside of my favorite Mexican food restaurant, these are the best pork carnitas I've had. Follow the instructions. Don't skimp on cooking time. Definitely use cast iron with a tight fitting lid. I have four sons; when it's quiet at the dinner table, I know it's a keeper! Yum!

My husband and his brother really liked these. I used less salt, more garlic and less chicken broth ( and will use only 2 cups next time) I thickened the leftover sauce and stirred most of it into the shredded meat. Super easy and I will definitely add it to my list of easy casual meals to make for extended family.
May I suggest adding squeezed orange juice over the meat before putting in the oven. I cook mine for hours in the oven as opposed to boiling but boiling is most often referenced in recipes.
I've tried multiple Carnitas recipes from this site. This was by far the best and most authentic tasting. I'll be sticking with this one.
Followed the recipe as written. It was delicious! My family all loved it!
My Mexican wife approved

Excellent to do pork shoulder butt for making pulled pork. Instead of using canned broth, I used chicken bouillon powder, one tbs. per one cup water. 5 cups total. Plus I had a 7 pound pork butt. Great taste.
I didn't really change anything except quantity, They were great and easy enough to make. Thanks Nette.
This is now our go to recipe for making carnitas. Followed the recipe and it came out great
I made with pork ribs... so very good! Will do again with Boston butt roast or pork shoulder.
The only change I made was I used a crockpot for the first cooking. I cooked it on low for 8-9 hours. They turned out so tender and flavorful.

This was absolutely amazing! I decided to marinade the shoulder in all of the other ingredients for 2 days before cooking it all as described. It was the best carnitas I've ever had, let alone made myself. I will DEFINITELY be making this again!!

Carnitas at home is either bland or too salty and I’ve tried MANY online recipes. This one however, is a keeper. Prepared as recipe stated except I shredded the evening’s dinner portion, added a bit of broth and put under broiler to crisp top to perfection. Took just under 10 min., keep an eye out for it.
Full of flavor, and delicious on a plate with beans and rice or in a burrito or quesadilla. I’ve tried them all, served for family, kid and husband approved. Good recipe for parties and potluck.
This is my Mexican go to recipe. Everyone loves it. I make it exactly like the recipe says. Serve it with warm tortllas, pico de gallo, grated cotija cheese, chopped cilantro and onion.
This recipe is the BOMB!!! We topped with pico, avocado, queso fresco, fresh jals and cilantro. Washed them down with my man’s fresh margaritas... perfect Friday night!!!

I’ve made this about twenty times and we love it. I try to get a bone in oversized roast if possible. I don’t salt the product at all until the broiling phase and I also cook in a dutch oven at a very, very slight simmer til falling apart.
I followed the recipe exactly (but I cooked it in a pressure cooker). It was delicious.

I made this after reading all the amazing reviews. Upped the garlic, used cola, etc. I was prepared to be transported. While they were good, they were not ethereally delicious. The consistency of the meat was mostly the issue, it was tender and shredded easily but was not unctuous, which is what I was after. I used a Dutch oven, followed all steps to the letter. I was afraid to leave them in the oven too long for fear of drying them out. Meat not fatty enough? Did they need to cook longer on a lower temp? Happy for any tips!
This was awesome! Easy to make, and no leftovers. I’m looking forward to making this again.
A little dry and we like stronger flavors.
The best!!!
I used jalapeño powder also as part of the species.
So good!
Perfect spices. Don’t need to bake - just slow-cooked 9 lbs, pulled it apart, then let it marinate covered in the fridge overnight. Freeze half. Heat on the stove and stuff tacos. Perfection.
This was outstanding! My meat was very tender after just an hour of simmering but other than that I followed the recipe. I will definitely be making this again!

An American living in Paris, France, so I hunger often for Mexican food as there are no good restaurants here. I had to bring a couple of spices from my last trip to California before the world turned upside down. I finally made this today and it is heaven in my mouth. Carnitas was always my favorite Mexican food. Even though cuts of meat are different I used a pork roast with a huge bone in it, which my dog will enjoy tomorrow. The only thing I did differently was cut down amount of salt to 1 tablespoon. It cooked on top of the stove for a couple of hours and then transferred to the oven where it was basted periodically. It was so delicious and I will be making some black beans tomorrow to make burritos. Absolutely easy and delicious

OMG! This recipe is amazing. I accidently bought pork for carnitas. So, I looked up this recipe and WOW! I love it! Honestly, I normally dislike shredded meat! Not this. I followed the recipe exactly only adjusting it down for the lesser amount of pork. This is a new save for sure!! Thank you!! amazing!

I cooked this in my Instant Pot using the ingredients listed. When it was done, I put a little caramelization to the pork and onions using my crisping lid. Then I fried two tortillas with cheese between them (like quesadillas). We filled the cheese filled tortillas with the carnitas and added fresh chopped cilantro, avocado, and tomato. Topped with a sauce of sour cream, mayonnaise, lime juice, sugar, cumin, and chipotle hot sauce. We rolled or folded them and used a lot of napkins. DELICIOUS!!
Made this for a family dinner tonight. Everyone loved it. This recipe is a keeper.
A little salty, but it's so packed with flavor and juciy! Sprinkle a little salsa, maybe some grilled onions, and a little bit of jalapenos and this turns out perfect!

Absolutely delicious- my only recommendation is to put only 1 Tblsp of salt on the meat when it’s browning and use a box of low sodium chicken broth- the seasoning was spot on when I did this. I used the meat to stuff into arepas with cheese and avocado & it was of restaurant quality!
I cooked exactly as written and the pork was delicious!

I used no salt chicken stock instead of chicken broth. Chicken stock always has more flavor than broth. I did use the listed amount of salt. I also put big chunks of onions along side of the pork when it was in the oven. My husband and I will not be making this recipe again it would take to many alterations to even make it good for our taste buds
They was the best I ever made, I have made many! This will be the only way I make them for now on.
Update on my review: this freezes very well for those who like to cook ahead.

Wow, this recipe is right on! I love the subtle seasoning flavor which enhances the pork flavor so that it still tastes like pork. I cooked the meat to perfection then let it cool in the liquid until just warm. This creates the perfect texture!! Then put it in foil lined pan and on the grill for just a few minutes each side for slight crispiness!! I also wrapped the street corn tortillas in foil and put on the upper shelf of the grill to warm. Chopped onion and cilantro and taco perfection!!! I didn’t even add hot sauce because the pork is so flavorful on its own!!! Thank you Nette!
This recipe was simple, delicious and versatile! We bought a rather large picnic roast and used it for tacos, pulled pork sandwiches and soup, all in the same week. It’s a keeper for sure!

I will definitely make this again. I made it exactly as the recipe states w/ 2 exceptions. I used a pork loin roast because that is what I had in the freezer. I also forgot to cut it into chunks before browning it. I browned all sides whole. Because the roast was whole it took a little longer to cook on the stove, about 30 more minutes. We ate it on toasted corn tortillas w/ mild onion, cilantro and lime juice. It was so delicious. Next time I will make marinated red onions to go on top.
Delicious! Made as stated and so tender. They were even better the next day as leftovers!
Super easy, flavorful, perfect
Was wonderful I personally added one bottle of Guinness to replace same amount of liquid and two bay leaves. I came out so well I was asked to make it again

5 star! 
followed exactly and turned out fantastic! I'm married to a Hispanic for 45 years and this was a keeper from his mouth! I did use New Mexico red chili for the chili powder and it gave a small bite
Amazing. I took some other people's suggestions and cut the amount of salt by half, was perfect for our tastes. We used hard shell tacos and tasted great.
A bit salty but maybe used too much sauce when baking. Otherwise super good and easy to make.

Very good! Tons of flavor and cooked well in the crock pot. I did everything in a skillet until it was time to cook for 21/2 hours. I transferred everything to the crock pot added more broth and let it cook on low for about 5 hours. Really tasty.
Wonderful. Only change, less salt. I used 1 tablespoon. Definitely a repeat!!

Outstanding recipe! I did not have chicken broth on hand. So I made a broth with Worchestshire sauce and water. Very good substitute. Followed directions otherwise. Family devoured it! Will definitely make again!

I cut the recipe in half and the salt was over powering. I would make it again but with less salt next time. Kosher salt is over powering if not done right, The seasons from what I could taste were pretty good.
I need to cook and practice more to get it perfect but for the first time it was very delicious!

Excelled recipe. Meat is fork-tender even without a Dutch oven as long as the chunks are (almost completely) covered by the liquid. I seasoned with salt to my preference and adjusted at the end when it went in the oven. I also recommending adding more lime in the broth or squeezing additional sauce when it goes in the oven.
Delicious. Made it exactly like the recipe. Will make it again soon. Very flavorful and simple. Served with rice and raw veggies with lime hive and cilantro. Yum.

When I make this recipe, I put half way for another day because if I put it all out, there will not be anything left! They are perfect, just perfect! If it’s summer, I leave the oven off and crisp on my stovetop. Or, I just warm them up on my stove- they are very moist this way. My kids love them and so does my hubby. He actually does not like Mexican food, but he LOVES these carnitas!

I made it using the pressure cooker. First browned meat as specified...when I added the broth, I started the pressure cooking. All done in 35 minutes. Absolutely delicious. I salted to my taste so I had no problem.

Really simple recipe, but amazingly delicious! I used unsalted chicken stock and salted moderately before searing and then to taste at the end. I do agree that 3T as well as salted chix stock might be too much for most. Thanks for sharing this recipe!
Easy, delicious, crowd pleaser
Bangin! Everybody else has said enough. It's all true.

Spend the time to make sure all the fat is crisped when you start..More like 15-20 of browning..

Double the Cumin.
Double the Garlic..
Double the Oregano..
Solid Recipe that will have anyone asking for seconds..

Nice recipe, I have made a few.
My last step comes after shredding. I will melt a bit of lard in my cast iron skillet. When it just begins to smoke I'll drop in some shredded pork and let it get crispy, stir before burning.

This recipe is amazing. I do the first stage of cooking in a slow cooker the day ahead and reheat in oven with reserved stock and avocado oil. I serve with warm corn tortillas, fresh guacamole and homemade tomatillo salsa. This brings a lot of smiles to a lot of faces.
Amazing recipe. Can’t recommend enough
I will add a little liquid smoke next time but the recipe is very good. I’ve cooked it twice and a real crowd pleaser both times.
SO SO SO good, I would make it again and again and again! Thank you!
My husband does not like Cummin so I can't put that in . But other than that it turned out pretty tasty.
They were delicious!!! Will make again.

This is an excellent recipe. Normally I make and review recipes exactly as written but I did change a couple of spices based on other reviews. I omitted the cinnamon and Chinese 5 spice, and added 2 tsp chili powder, 1/2 tsp cumin and 1 tsp oregano as per Chef John's suggestion. I also added 1 yellow onion chunked just because we love onion. It was flavored perfectly and had the richness we've been searching for that has been missing in other recipes. I did a chunky shred before broiling and it was easy to make the tacos. Served with pico de gallo, lime and sour cream, this is a fabulous recipe and will be my go-to from now on. Bravo Chef John!

Delicious! I have made this a couple of times and we love it!

Prefer this over pulled pork with BBC sauce.

So good!
Awesome. The whole family loved it. Super easy to make.
Have made this twice. It was a hit both times
Loved it! Didn’t change anything. So easy and so good!!
It is good, I just always have issues with it coming out dry. As the author suggests, shoulder or butt is better than loin, which is what I used. It is very delicious, and versatile.
This recipe is delicious! The only thing I did differently is, I seasoned the pork with a pork brine mixture of salt, pepper, orange peel, and other ingredients.
Excellent recipe..just added a bit more garlic..definitely a keeper! I also added more lime juice as I have a glut of limes falling off our tree!
Delicious, easy to make carnitas!

Muy deliciouso!!! I cooked mine in a crockpot like some other reviewers then finished it off under the broiler. I sautéed some onion, green pepper and yellow squash and used it and the pork to make burritos verde de puerco. Our local Mexican joint may have lost a customer!

I used a 4# pork loin roast and cut off the fat. Cut into 2" pieces and sauteed in a large skillet until browned, then added the rest of the ingredients, then added the broth. Simmered for 2 hours, then shredded in the pot. I didn't crisp in the oven & I didn't add any salt, we are watching our salt intake, so I have to watch that. Excellent recipe and served with refried beans, flour tortillas, salsa, sour cream, fresh diced tomatoes and it was wonderful!

This taste soooooo good! After I follow the recipe, I put a layer of the shredded pork on a very HOT skillet. Let it crisp up like how the restaurants serve it down here in Texas. .. so don't mix/stir until it gets crispy (8-10min). Only let it crisp on one side so you'll get the yummy crispy meat & some tender meat.
Delicious as written. I quick fry corn tortillas (20 seconds each side) then drain on paper towels. I make Cole slaw and layer the pork and Cole slaw on top of the tortillas. Delicious!
Great everyone enjoyed it.

Loved it! Omitted onion due to dietary restrictions; used 1 tsp of onion power instead. Added pork to salad with red pepper, cilantro and cheese and made chipotle-ranch dressing. Delicious!! Thanks Nette

Our whole family loves this meal. All I change is I salt and pepper grind the meat before browning. Low sodium chicken broth and juice of three limes. I don’t add any extra salt until the broiling method and usually add 10 to 20 minutes to the broiling time. This is also great sprinkled on some eggs with sriracha.
Made this not changing any ingredients, but cooking it in a crock pot for about 9 hours and it came out really good.

I have made this at least 20 times since finding this recipe a few years ago, so I can't believe I'm just now reviewing it. TRULY 5-STAR. It is gobbled up by my picky kids and discerning foodie taco party guests alike. I love that no one spice or flavor tries to steal the spotlight - they all just work together to create this masterpiece of juicy, crisp-edged, porky bliss. As some reviewers note (and I believe the original author), the garlic amount should be a full head of garlic, i.e. all the cloves peeled and smashed with the side of a knife. Simply amazing.
The family loved it. We made tacos

Delicious recipe. I used a boneless pork butt. I read the reviews put in less salt than the recipe called for. That was a mistake as I had to add salt to the the finished product. Next time I will add the stated amount. The 30 minutes in the oven did not seem to crisp up the carnitas the way I wanted, so I put the pan of carnitas under the broiler for a couple of minutes to crisp up. Delicious. Will definitely make this again.

I have to say, this is the first recipe for carnitas that I have tried and it will be the one I make forever! It is so flavorful ??. I stuck to the recipe guidelines except I cut the pork butt down to under 3 pounds. It’s only me and I didn’t want 5-6 pounds of left over pork. The flavor infused well. I recommend this recipe with a healthy portion of pico de Gallo and guacamole with warm flour tortillas.

This was superb, however I substituted some orange juice for half of the liquid and no salt homemade chicken stock. Also swapped out apple cider vinegar for the lime juice. Came out supremely flavorful, tasted wonderful on some corn tortillas with salsa, sour cream and lettuce!

DARN GOOD carnitas! This recipe might as well be carNEATas, it’s so simple and distinct. I’ve seen other recipes call for blending Turkey livers into the meat...what?! Why would anyone sully this swine with fowl meat? I found that inserting garlic hunks into the meat prior to simmering adds a wonderfully complex aroma. Seriously though, Turkey livers?? What the heck!
Very easy to make and very flavorful! Adding serrano chilies would make this a 5 star recipe in my opinion. Definitely keeping this recipe within easy reach.

Turned out really well. We had enough to turn them into 2 meals. One soft -tacos with cabbage instead of lettuce and the other half into a mexican style rice and beans meal. Thank you for a great recipe. My husband really liked them and has asked that I make them again on a regular rotation.

This was awesome! Husband and children approved. I did only use 2T salt instead of three and that was perfect for us. I know she says you can use a bulb of garlic but I thought the 1 clove was great. We will definitely be making this again.

Great! The only changes I made were using a much larger pork shoulder cut into pieces, homemade broth, 2 cans of beer (extra we didn't particularly like), a little liquid smoke and salt to taste. Served it with a lime & cilantro slaw in corn tortillas. Yum! All the adults and kids liked it, even my one who says she doesn't like pork. Very flavorful. Yum!!
I've made this several times and it is fantastic! I don't even brown the pieces after it simmers and it's still amazing.
